Medical malpractice attorney San Diego

If you suspect that you or a loved one has been a victim of medical malpractice in San Diego, its crucial to take immediate and thoughtful steps to protect your rights and seek justice. Medical malpractice can have devastating consequences, and navigating the legal landscape requires diligence and expertise. Here are the key steps to consider:

First and foremost, seek medical attention. If you believe that a healthcare providers actions have harmed you, prioritize your health and well-being by getting the necessary medical care. This may involve seeing a different doctor for a second opinion or undergoing additional treatments to address any complications caused by the suspected malpractice.

Next, gather and preserve all relevant medical records and documentation. This includes obtaining copies of medical records, lab results, prescriptions, and any correspondence with healthcare providers. Detailed documentation will be crucial for a San Diego medical malpractice lawyer to assess your case and build a strong claim.

Its also important to document your experience thoroughly. Keep a journal detailing your symptoms, treatments, and interactions with healthcare providers. Note specific dates, times, and names of medical personnel involved. This personal account can provide valuable context and evidence when pursuing a malpractice claim.

Consulting with a specialized medical malpractice lawyer in San Diego is a critical step. Medical malpractice cases are complex and require an attorney with specific expertise in this area of law. A knowledgeable lawyer can evaluate your case, determine whether you have a viable claim, and guide you through the legal process. They can also help you understand the statute of limitations for filing a malpractice lawsuit in California, ensuring that you take timely action.

Before meeting with a lawyer, prepare a list of questions and concerns. This will help you make the most of your consultation and ensure that all aspects of your case are addressed. An experienced attorney will explain your legal options, potential outcomes, and the steps involved in pursuing a claim.

Its also advisable to refrain from discussing your case with anyone other than your lawyer. Statements made to insurance companies, healthcare providers, or on social media can be used against you in legal proceedings. Your attorney will handle all communications and negotiations on your behalf, protecting your interests and strengthening your case.

Understanding the emotional toll of medical malpractice is also essential. Such experiences can be traumatic, and seeking support from friends, family, or a professional counselor can help you cope with the stress and anxiety that often accompany these situations.

Lastly, be prepared for a potentially lengthy legal process. Medical malpractice cases can take time to resolve, involving extensive investigation, expert testimony, and negotiations. Patience and perseverance are key, and your lawyer will work diligently to achieve the best possible outcome for you.

In conclusion, if you suspect medical malpractice in San Diego, taking prompt and informed action is vital. Prioritize your health, document your experience, consult with a specialized lawyer, and seek emotional support. By following these steps, you can protect your rights and pursue the justice you deserve.

How to file a medical malpractice lawsuit in San Diego

Dealing with the aftermath of medical malpractice can be an overwhelming and daunting experience. In San Diego, where healthcare facilities are numerous and varied, patients trust medical professionals with their lives, expecting the highest standard of care. Unfortunately, when this trust is breached, the consequences can be devastating. This is where a San Diego medical malpractice lawyer steps in, offering invaluable assistance to those affected by medical negligence.

First and foremost, a medical malpractice lawyer offers expertise and a thorough understanding of the complex legal landscape surrounding medical negligence cases. Medical malpractice law is intricate, involving a deep knowledge of both legal and medical concepts. A specialized lawyer can effectively navigate these complexities, ensuring that victims understand their rights and the legal options available to them. They are adept at evaluating the specifics of a case, identifying whether there is a viable claim, and advising on the best course of action.

One of the critical roles of a medical malpractice lawyer is to investigate the incident in question meticulously. This involves gathering and scrutinizing medical records, consulting with medical experts, and piecing together the sequence of events that led to the alleged malpractice. This thorough investigation is crucial for building a strong case, as it provides the necessary evidence to demonstrate that a medical professionals negligence resulted in harm to the patient.

Furthermore, a San Diego medical malpractice lawyer acts as a fierce advocate for their client, both in and out of the courtroom. They are responsible for negotiating settlements with insurance companies and opposing legal teams, ensuring that the victim receives fair compensation for their suffering. This compensation can cover medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and other related costs. If a fair settlement cannot be reached, the lawyer is prepared to take the case to trial, presenting a compelling argument to the jury on behalf of their client.

In addition to their legal expertise, a medical malpractice lawyer provides emotional support and guidance during a difficult time. Victims of medical malpractice often feel a sense of betrayal and confusion. Having a compassionate lawyer who understands the emotional toll of such experiences can make a significant difference. They offer reassurance and keep clients informed throughout the legal process, alleviating some of the stress and uncertainty.

Moreover, engaging a medical malpractice lawyer can also have a broader impact. By holding medical professionals and institutions accountable for their actions, these lawyers play a crucial role in promoting higher standards of care within the healthcare system. Their work can lead to changes in policies and practices that prevent future instances of negligence, ultimately benefiting the wider community.

In San Diego, where the healthcare industry is a vital part of the community, the role of a medical malpractice lawyer is indispensable. They provide the expertise, advocacy, and support needed to navigate the challenging aftermath of medical negligence. By doing so, they help victims rebuild their lives and seek justice, ensuring that those responsible are held accountable for their actions.

Choosing a lawyer is a critical decision, especially when dealing with something as complex and emotional as a medical malpractice case in San Diego. Look for a lawyer who has a proven track record in handling medical malpractice cases specifically. Check their history of successful settlements and verdicts in similar cases. An experienced lawyer will not only understand the legal landscape but will also have established relationships with medical experts who can provide crucial testimony to support your case.

Secondly, consider the lawyers reputation. Reputation can be a strong indicator of a lawyers ability to handle your case effectively. Look for reviews and testimonials from past clients. You can also check with local bar associations and online legal directories for any disciplinary actions or complaints against the lawyer. A lawyer with a solid reputation is likely to be more reliable and trustworthy.

Another critical factor is communication. Effective communication is essential for understanding the complexities of your case and the legal strategies involved. Your lawyer should be able to explain complicated medical and legal terms in a way that you can understand. They should also be responsive to your calls and emails, providing updates on your cases progress and answering any questions you might have. A lawyer who is approachable and communicative can alleviate much of the stress and anxiety that comes with a medical malpractice case.

The lawyers resources and support staff are also important considerations. Medical malpractice cases often require extensive resources, including medical experts, investigators, and administrative support. A well-established law firm with ample resources can thoroughly investigate your case, gather necessary evidence, and build a strong case on your behalf. Ensure that the lawyer has a competent team to support the various aspects of your case.

Additionally, consider the lawyers fee structure. Medical malpractice cases can be expensive, and its essential to understand the financial implications before you commit. Many medical malpractice lawyers work on a contingency fee basis, meaning they only get paid if you win your case. Make sure to discuss and understand all potential costs and fees upfront, so there are no surprises down the line.

Lastly, trust your instincts. After meeting with a potential lawyer, reflect on how comfortable and confident you feel about their abilities. Its crucial to have a lawyer who you believe will vigorously represent your interests and who you feel comfortable working with over what could be a prolonged period.

In conclusion, choosing the right San Diego medical malpractice lawyer involves careful consideration of their experience, reputation, communication skills, resources, fee structure, and your personal comfort level. By taking the time to evaluate these factors, you can select a lawyer who is well-equipped to navigate the complexities of your case and advocate for the justice and compensation you deserve.

When facing the aftermath of a medical malpractice incident, understanding the potential outcomes and compensation is crucial. Medical malpractice cases are complex, and having a knowledgeable San Diego medical malpractice lawyer by your side can make all the difference in navigating this challenging terrain.

Medical malpractice occurs when a healthcare professional deviates from the standard of care, resulting in harm to the patient. The consequences of such deviations can be devastating, leading to physical, emotional, and financial distress. In San Diego, as in other parts of the country, victims of medical malpractice have the right to seek compensation for their injuries and losses.

One of the primary outcomes of a successful medical malpractice claim is securing compensation for the victim. This compensation can cover a wide range of damages, including medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and even punitive damages in cases of gross negligence. Medical expenses can be particularly burdensome, encompassing costs for surgeries, hospital stays, medications, rehabilitation, and ongoing care. A skilled San Diego medical malpractice lawyer will work to ensure that these costs are thoroughly documented and included in the claim.

Lost wages are another significant factor. If the victim is unable to work due to their injuries, they may be entitled to compensation for the income they have lost and will continue to lose in the future. This can also extend to loss of earning capacity if the victim is no longer able to perform the same job or work the same number of hours as before the incident.

Pain and suffering damages address the emotional and psychological impact of the malpractice. This can include compensation for physical pain, mental anguish, loss of enjoyment of life, and other non-economic damages. Calculating these damages can be complex, but an experienced lawyer will know how to present a compelling case to ensure the victim receives fair compensation.

In some cases, punitive damages may be awarded. These are intended to punish the healthcare provider for particularly egregious conduct and to deter similar behavior in the future. While punitive damages are not awarded in every case, they can significantly increase the total compensation if the healthcare providers actions were especially reckless or intentional.

The potential outcomes of a medical malpractice case also include the resolution process itself. Some cases may be settled out of court through negotiations between the victims lawyer and the healthcare providers insurance company. Settlements can provide a quicker resolution and avoid the uncertainty of a trial, but it is essential to have a lawyer who can negotiate effectively and ensure that any settlement offer is fair and adequate.

If a settlement cannot be reached, the case may proceed to trial. A trial can be a lengthy and stressful process, but it may be necessary to achieve a just outcome. A San Diego medical malpractice lawyer will prepare meticulously for trial, gathering evidence, consulting with medical experts, and building a strong case to present to the jury.

Ultimately, the goal of pursuing a medical malpractice claim is to secure the compensation needed to help the victim rebuild their life. The road to recovery can be long and arduous, but with the right legal representation, victims can have the financial support they need to move forward. In San Diego, medical malpractice lawyers play a vital role in advocating for those who have been wronged by the very professionals entrusted with their care, ensuring that justice is served and that victims receive the compensation they deserve.

Here, we discuss some of the most prevalent forms of medical malpractice cases that attorneys encounter.

One of the most common types of medical malpractice cases involves misdiagnosis or delayed diagnosis. When a healthcare professional incorrectly diagnoses a condition or fails to diagnose it in a timely manner, the consequences can be severe. A misdiagnosis can lead to incorrect treatments, unnecessary procedures, or a lack of treatment altogether, potentially worsening the patient's condition. In San Diego, where healthcare facilities are abundant, the importance of accurate diagnosis cannot be overstated. Patients rely on their doctors to identify their ailments correctly, and when that trust is broken, the results can be devastating.

Surgical errors represent another frequent category of medical malpractice cases. These errors can occur during any type of surgery, from minor outpatient procedures to major operations. Examples include operating on the wrong body part, leaving surgical instruments inside the patient, or causing damage to organs or tissues that were not part of the surgery. Surgical errors often lead to additional medical complications, prolonged recovery times, and, in some cases, irreversible damage. For those affected, the physical and emotional toll can be immense, making it crucial to seek the expertise of an experienced medical malpractice attorney in San Diego.

Medication errors are also a significant concern in the realm of medical malpractice. These errors can happen at various stages, including prescribing the wrong medication, incorrect dosage, or even errors in the administration of the drug. Medication errors can lead to adverse reactions, ineffective treatment, and in severe cases, death. The fast-paced environment of hospitals and clinics in San Diego can sometimes contribute to these mistakes, but that does not absolve healthcare providers of their responsibility to ensure patient safety.

Birth injuries are another critical area where medical malpractice can occur. These cases involve injuries to the baby or mother during the labor and delivery process. Common birth injuries include cerebral palsy, Erb's palsy, and other conditions that can result from improper use of delivery instruments, failure to monitor fetal distress, or delayed C-section operations. The impact of birth injuries is often lifelong, affecting not only the child but the entire family. In such emotionally charged situations, a knowledgeable medical malpractice attorney in San Diego can provide the necessary guidance and support.

Lastly, failure to obtain informed consent is a type of medical malpractice that occurs when a healthcare provider does not adequately inform the patient about the risks, benefits, and alternatives of a proposed treatment or procedure. Patients have the right to make informed decisions about their medical care. When this right is violated, it can lead to unexpected complications and a loss of trust in the healthcare system.

In conclusion, medical malpractice encompasses a variety of negligent actions by healthcare providers that can have serious repercussions for patients. Misdiagnosis, surgical errors, medication errors, birth injuries, and failure to obtain informed consent are some of the most common types of medical malpractice cases seen by attorneys in San Diego. Expert testimony in medical malpractice cases serves multiple critical functions. First and foremost, it provides the court with specialized knowledge that bridges the gap between intricate medical facts and legal standards. Medical malpractice is inherently technical, involving detailed examinations of medical procedures, diagnoses, and standards of care. An expert witness, usually a seasoned medical professional, can elucidate these complexities, helping the judge and jury understand whether the healthcare provider's actions deviated from accepted medical practices.

In San Diego, where the medical community is both vast and specialized, the selection of an appropriate expert witness is a nuanced task. An experienced medical malpractice attorney leverages their extensive network to identify experts whose credentials and expertise align perfectly with the specifics of the case. In these situations, potential damages and compensation play a critical role in addressing the aftermath of medical errors.

Damages in medical malpractice claims are typically categorized into three types: economic, non-economic, and, in some cases, punitive. Economic damages are quantifiable financial losses incurred by the patient, such as medical bills, rehabilitation costs, and lost wages. These damages are essential as they directly address the out-of-pocket expenses that the patient has borne due to the malpractice.

Non-economic damages, on the other hand, are more subjective and encompass the intangible impacts of malpractice. These include pain and suffering, emotional distress, loss of enjoyment of life, and loss of consortium. Calculating these damages can be challenging, as they do not come with a clear price tag. An experienced medical malpractice attorney in San Diego can effectively articulate these damages, ensuring that the patient's suffering is adequately represented and compensated.

In rare cases, punitive damages may be awarded. These are not intended to compensate the patient but to punish the healthcare provider for particularly egregious conduct and to deter similar behavior in the future. Punitive damages are less common in medical malpractice cases, but they serve as a critical tool for addressing extreme negligence or malicious intent.

These legal professionals have a deep understanding of the complexities involved in medical malpractice claims, including the nuances of California state law. They can gather and present compelling evidence, work with medical experts to substantiate claims, and negotiate aggressively with insurance companies and opposing counsel.

Moreover, a seasoned attorney can provide invaluable support and guidance throughout the legal process, offering a sense of stability and reassurance during what is often a tumultuous time. They understand the importance of a timely resolution and will work diligently to ensure that their clients receive the compensation they deserve as swiftly as possible.

In conclusion, potential damages and compensation are central to medical malpractice claims, addressing both the tangible and intangible losses suffered by patients. For those in San Diego, enlisting the help of an experienced medical malpractice attorney is crucial in navigating these claims effectively. Such legal expertise ensures that patients are not only heard but also adequately compensated for their suffering, paving the way for a more just and equitable resolution.

When a healthcare provider fails to diagnose a condition accurately or in a timely manner, it can lead to incorrect or delayed treatment, worsening the patient's condition. For example, if a doctor misinterprets test results or overlooks symptoms, a treatable illness like cancer could progress to an advanced stage, significantly reducing the patient's chances of recovery. Misdiagnosis or delayed diagnosis cases frequently form the basis for medical malpractice claims, as they often result in severe harm or even death.

Surgical errors are another common category of medical malpractice. These errors can occur during any type of surgical procedure, whether it's a routine operation or a complex, high-stakes surgery. Examples of surgical errors include operating on the wrong body part, leaving surgical instruments inside the patient's body, or causing unintended damage to organs and tissues. Such mistakes can lead to significant complications, infections, prolonged recovery times, and additional surgeries. Patients who suffer from surgical errors often face a long and painful road to recovery, making it essential to hold the responsible parties accountable.

Medication errors also represent a significant portion of medical malpractice cases. These errors can occur at various stages, from prescribing the wrong medication or dosage to administering the drug incorrectly. For instance, a doctor might prescribe a medication that interacts negatively with a patient's existing medications, or a nurse might administer the wrong dosage, leading to harmful side effects or overdose. Given the critical role that medication plays in treating illnesses and managing conditions, such errors can have severe and sometimes fatal consequences.

Birth injuries are a particularly heart-wrenching type of medical malpractice case. These injuries can occur due to negligence during prenatal care, labor, or delivery. Examples include failing to monitor the baby's vital signs adequately, improper use of delivery instruments like forceps or vacuum extractors, and delays in performing a necessary cesarean section. Birth injuries can result in lifelong disabilities for the child, such as cerebral palsy or Erb's palsy, profoundly impacting the child's quality of life and placing a significant emotional and financial burden on the family.

Lastly, anesthesia errors are another common type of medical malpractice. Anesthesiologists are responsible for administering anesthesia safely and monitoring the patient's vital signs during surgery. Mistakes in this area can include administering too much or too little anesthesia, failing to recognize and respond to anesthesia-related complications, or improper intubation. Such errors can lead to severe complications, including brain damage, nerve damage, or even death.

When a healthcare provider fails to diagnose a condition correctly or in a timely manner, the consequences can be dire. For instance, a delayed cancer diagnosis can lead to the disease progressing to an advanced stage, drastically reducing the patient's chances of successful treatment. A misdiagnosis can also result in unnecessary treatments that can cause harm or exacerbate the actual condition. In such scenarios, an experienced medical malpractice lawyer can help establish that the standard of care was not met and that this failure directly led to harm.

Surgical errors are another common form of medical malpractice. These can range from operating on the wrong body part to leaving surgical instruments inside a patient's body. The repercussions of surgical mistakes can be severe, leading to additional surgeries, prolonged recovery times, and sometimes even permanent disability or death. A proficient lawyer in San Diego can scrutinize surgical records and expert testimonies to build a compelling case that highlights the breach in standard care.

Medication errors also constitute a significant portion of medical malpractice cases. These errors can occur at various stages, from prescribing the wrong medication or dosage to administering the incorrect drug. Such mistakes can lead to adverse reactions, worsening of the medical condition, or even fatal outcomes. A seasoned lawyer can investigate the chain of events and determine where the lapse occurred, ensuring that the responsible parties are held accountable.

Birth injuries, unfortunately, form another category of medical malpractice. These cases involve harm to the newborn or the mother during the birthing process. Examples include brain injuries due to oxygen deprivation, fractures, and nerve damage. The emotional and physical toll on the family can be immense, necessitating a lawyer's involvement to seek compensation for medical expenses, pain, and suffering.

Lastly, anesthesia errors are also a critical aspect of medical malpractice. Mistakes in administering anesthesia can result in severe complications such as brain damage, nerve injury, or even death. These cases often require a thorough understanding of both medical procedures and legal standards. A competent lawyer can collaborate with medical experts to establish negligence and secure the necessary compensation for the affected parties.

They can provide the necessary support, gather pertinent evidence, and advocate for your rights, ensuring that justice is served and that you receive the compensation you deserve.

Filing a medical malpractice claim can be a complex and daunting process, particularly in a bustling city like San Diego, CA. However, understanding the steps involved can help demystify the process and empower victims to seek the justice they deserve. Here's a detailed look at the steps involved in filing a medical malpractice claim.

The first crucial step is to consult a qualified medical malpractice lawyer. In San Diego, there are numerous experienced attorneys who specialize in this field. An initial consultation will enable the lawyer to assess the merits of your case and advise you on the best course of action. This is a vital step because medical malpractice law is intricate and requires specialized knowledge to navigate effectively.

Once you've retained a lawyer, the next step is to gather all pertinent medical records. Your attorney will help you obtain these documents, which are essential for establishing the facts of your case. This includes medical reports, prescriptions, and any other relevant documentation that can demonstrate negligence or substandard care. The thoroughness of this step cannot be overstated, as these records form the backbone of your claim.

The subsequent step involves a thorough investigation. Your lawyer will likely collaborate with medical experts to scrutinize the details of your treatment. These experts will provide an objective analysis of whether the care you received deviated from accepted medical standards. Their testimony is often crucial in substantiating your claim.

Following the investigation, your attorney will draft a demand letter. This letter outlines the facts of the case, the negligence involved, and the damages you are seeking. It is sent to the healthcare provider or their insurance company as a formal request for compensation. This step often initiates settlement negotiations, which can resolve the matter without going to court.

If a settlement cannot be reached, the next step is to file a formal lawsuit. Your lawyer will prepare the necessary legal documents and file them with the appropriate court in San Diego. This initiates the litigation process, which can be lengthy and complex. The filing must occur within the statute of limitations, which in California is generally three years from the date of injury or one year from the date the injury was discovered.

Following the filing, the discovery phase begins. Both parties exchange information and gather evidence to build their respective cases. This phase can involve depositions, interrogatories, and document requests. The objective is to uncover all relevant facts and build a compelling case for trial.

As the discovery phase concludes, the case moves towards trial. Pre-trial motions and hearings may occur, where both sides argue specific points of law or seek to exclude certain evidence. Finally, the trial itself takes place, where both sides present their arguments, evidence, and witness testimony before a judge or jury.

Throughout this process, having a skilled medical malpractice lawyer in San Diego is invaluable. They will guide you through each step, advocate on your behalf, and strive to secure the best possible outcome for your case. While the process can be challenging, understanding these steps can help you navigate the complexities of filing a medical malpractice claim and work towards obtaining the justice and compensation you deserve.

**Common Challenges in Medical Malpractice Lawsuits**

Medical malpractice lawsuits are inherently complex and fraught with numerous challenges. For individuals in San Diego, CA, who are considering legal action against healthcare providers, understanding these common hurdles can provide essential context and prepare them for the road ahead.

One of the primary challenges in medical malpractice lawsuits is proving negligence. Unlike other types of personal injury cases, medical malpractice requires the plaintiff to establish that the healthcare provider deviated from the accepted standard of care. This involves demonstrating that the practitioner’s actions were not just incorrect, but fell below the level of competence expected from reasonably skilled professionals in similar circumstances. Gathering sufficient evidence to meet this burden of proof often requires in-depth knowledge of medical practices and standards, making expert testimony indispensable.

Another significant obstacle is the statute of limitations. In California, the deadline to file a medical malpractice lawsuit is generally three years from the date of injury, or one year from the date the injury was discovered, whichever occurs first. Missing this deadline can result in the dismissal of the case, regardless of its merits. Therefore, time is of the essence, and potential plaintiffs must act promptly to ensure their right to seek compensation is preserved.

Medical malpractice cases also frequently encounter the challenge of causation. Even if it can be proven that the healthcare provider was negligent, plaintiffs must also show that this negligence directly caused their injury. This can be particularly difficult in medical contexts where patients often have pre-existing conditions or complex medical histories. Establishing a clear and direct link between the provider’s actions and the resultant harm typically requires comprehensive medical records and expert analysis.

Furthermore, securing expert witnesses presents its own set of difficulties. Medical experts are not only costly, but finding a credible and willing expert to testify can be challenging. These experts must be able to communicate complex medical information in a way that is understandable to a lay jury, all while withstanding rigorous cross-examination from defense attorneys.

Lastly, the emotional toll on plaintiffs can be substantial. Medical malpractice cases can be lengthy and stressful, often involving detailed personal medical histories and the reliving of traumatic experiences. Plaintiffs must be prepared for a potentially drawn-out legal process that can last several months, if not years. The emotional resilience required to navigate this journey should not be underestimated, and having a supportive legal team can make a significant difference.

In conclusion, medical malpractice lawsuits in San Diego, CA, involve several common challenges, including proving negligence, adhering to the statute of limitations, demonstrating causation, and securing expert witnesses, all while managing the emotional strain of the legal process. For those considering such action, consulting with an experienced medical malpractice lawyer is crucial to overcoming these hurdles and achieving a favorable outcome.

Another exception involves cases where a foreign object, such as a surgical instrument, is left inside a patient's body. In such scenarios, the statute of limitations does not begin until the patient discovers, or should have discovered, the object, regardless of the three-year absolute limit.

It is also important to note that the statute of limitations can be tolled, or paused, in certain situations. Navigating the challenging waters of a medical malpractice lawsuit can be a daunting experience, especially in a bustling city like San Diego, CA. Here’s a concise guide to the fundamental steps involved in a medical malpractice lawsuit.

With sufficient evidence in hand, the attorney will file a complaint or petition in the appropriate court. This legal document outlines the allegations against the healthcare provider or institution and specifies the damages being sought. Once the complaint is filed, the defendant, typically the healthcare provider, will be served with the lawsuit and given a specified period to respond.

Following the filing of the complaint, the discovery phase begins. This stage involves both parties exchanging information relevant to the case. Discovery can include depositions, interrogatories, and requests for documents. Depositions are particularly significant as they involve sworn testimony from parties and witnesses, which can be used in court. This phase can be lengthy and requires meticulous attention to detail from both the attorney and the client.

Mediation or settlement discussions often follow discovery. Many medical malpractice cases are resolved through settlement rather than going to trial. Trials can be unpredictable and lengthy, with the final decision resting in the hands of a judge or jury. The verdict will determine whether the plaintiff is entitled to damages and, if so, the amount.

In some instances, the losing party may choose to appeal the verdict. An appeal involves asking a higher court to review the case for legal errors that could have affected the outcome. Appeals are complex and can prolong the resolution of the case.
